Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ant Diversity of the MesoAmerican Corridor (ADMAC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
As the land bridge between the North and South America emerged, the fauna of the region had opportunities to diversify into novel ecological niches. The ants of the Mesoamerican corridor were particularly successful in rapidly diversifying over these new mountain ranges and plant communities. This project will develop a detailed biodiversity map for this ecologically dominant group of insects in a biogeographically important region of the world. The investigators will build on previous ant biodiversity collections and apply the latest techniques in genomics to identify species and investigate how geological history and contemporary ecological factors influence the distribution of biodiversity on tropical mountains.

Genomic methods for identifying species and their evolutionary relationships will revolutionize taxonomy and biodiversity studies, with subsequent benefits to other fields of science, agriculture, food inspection, public health, and invasive species detection. Improved understanding of the origin and distribution of mountain species within Mesoamerica is critical to evidenced-based conservation efforts and evaluation of the impacts of habitat conversion and climate change. Training in biodiversity science will occur at graduate and undergraduate levels at two public universities. The researchers will partner with the Natural History Museum of Utah to recruit undergraduates to science and reach out to the broader public, with an emphasis on underserved groups and quantifiable assessment of outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had three main goals: (1) to build a detailed biodiversity map for an ecologically dominant group of insects (ants) in a biogeographically important region of the world (the Mesoamerican corridor); (2) to develop and apply the latest techniques in genomics and next-generation DNA sequencing to biodiversity science; and (3) to use the results to understand how both geological history and contemporary ecological factors influence the distribution of species on tropical mountains.

Bi-national teams of students participated in field expeditions to Costa Rica and Mexico, carrying out a quantitative sampling protocol. These expeditions added to a large-scale community dataset for over 50 sites throughout Mesoamerica. The results revealed a robust relationship between diversity and elevation, with a diversity peak at 500 m elevation. Ant species have narrow zones of preferred elevation, and there is evidence that the diversity peak is due to ant species shifting upwards during the recent interglacial warming period. The results also reveal which species are restricted to one or a few mountain peaks, and thus in danger of extinction when there is further warming. The data are all publicly available and will be a lasting legacy that allows further monitoring of global change.

Genome-scale datasets were obtained for 3200 ant specimens. These data allow the reliable estimation of evolutionary relationships and the timing of species formation. Advances were made in analytical techniques that can be applied when such large amounts of sequence data are available. The project produced a detailed biodiversity map for multiple ant genera in Mesoamerica. The combination of geographic distribution and evolutionary history was used to identify how often and how rapidly montane specialization occurs, revealing that it occurs commonly and rapidly, with lowland ancestors frequently dividing into lowland and montane descendants.

The project's genomic methods for identifying species and their evolutionary relationships advanced taxonomy and biodiversity studies, with consequent benefits to other fields of science, agriculture, food inspection, public health, and invasive species detection. Improved understanding of the location and origin of mountain species within Mesoamerica is relevant to conservation efforts and evaluation of  the impacts of habitat conversion and climate change. There was a strong component of international collaboration among scientists and students, and new collaborations were formed with institutions in Mexico and Costa Rica. Training in biodiversity science occurred at graduate and undergraduate levels at two public universities. Activities at the Natural History Museum of Utah achieved outreach and science recruiting goals among undergraduates and the broader public, with emphasis on underserved groups.
